adjective.description: With no special or distinctive features; normal.
examples: he sets out to depict ordinary people
it was just an ordinary evening

adjective.description: (especially of a judge or bishop) exercising authority by virtue of office and not by delegation.

examples: their clichés were vested with enough emotion to elevate them above the ordinary

noun.description: A person, especially a judge, exercising authority by virtue of office and not by delegation.
Those parts of a Roman Catholic service, especially the Mass, which do not vary from day to day.
Any of the simplest principal charges used in coats of arms (especially chief, pale, bend, fess, bar, chevron, and saltire).
A meal provided at a fixed time and price at an inn.

phrases: nothing out of the ordinary happened
It is really, really strange because I haven't done anything out of the ordinary.
We're not going to do anything extravagant or anything that's out of the ordinary.
Nothing seemed unusual or out of the ordinary that morning, to her eyes, at least.
Finding something out of the ordinary for gardeners can be tricky and some themes crop up again and again this Christmas.
origin: Late Middle English: the noun partly via Old French; the adjective from Latin ordinarius orderly (reinforced by French ordinaire), from ordo, ordin- order.
